page.title: 05ROADS
page.content:
Away from the main roads one travels along minor roads only one car wide, and with their bends and high ditches often topped by hedges the view can be very restricted. Steep gradients, narrow bridges and rough surfaces also combine to make driving difficult. Most roads are lined with a bank of soil (the Devon Banks) and sometimes trees form an arch over the road. These banks may reach a height of a metre or more above the road and give you the feeling of walking in a large flower filled ditch.
Many of the hedges are now cut by tractors leaving an unattractive box like appearance, the old craft of laying a hedge being too time consuming for the modern farmer.
